newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Oct 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Oct 7.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Signs of a major rift have appeared in the New Aspiration Party when former secretary-general Sukhavich Rangsitphol voiced strong criticism of pary leader Chavalit Yongchaiyudh and complained he had been taken for granted. Sukhavich says he will demand a straight answer about his immediate future from Chavalit today, following the loss of his secretary-general's post to Snoh Thienthong, who led a mass defection of ex-members of parliament from the Chart Thai party. (THE NATION)

- More than 10,000 families have been stranded and schools have been closed after flash floods hit the northeastern province of Nakhon Ratchasima. Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa has ordered the mobilisation of government and military personnel to provide relief for flood victims nationwide. (THE NATION)

- Six Thai students released by Laos have been treated to a welcoming ceremony by villagers in the Thai border province of Nong Khai. The students had been held for illegal entry after crossing the border to compete in a soccer match in Vientiane. (BANGKOK POST)

- Commercial bank executives are pointing to the negative effects that the Bank of Thailand's latest measures to curb foreign capital inflow may have on the financial system as well as on profitability in the banking sector. Measures which the central bank introduced targeted commercial bank lending through both out-in and out-out International Banking FAcility. (BUSINESS DAY)

- Thai telecom firms and foreign equipment makers will bid on supplying a new transmission system, the purchase of which will cost the state-run Telephone Organisation of Thailand roughly 9 billion baht. (THE NATION)
